review: I have now purchased 2 Chromecasts.  I have one in my living room and one at my girlfriend's house.  Setup of the Chromecast with Netflix and HBO Go on our Android cell phones couldn't have been easier.  Now, either one of us can log in and take control of either TV... which allows us to see our own queues, and also pick up where we left off on either TV.  I don't think you can do that with the other more expensive hardware options (Roku, Apple TV, etc.)A downside for some of you:  Chromecast cannot natively support Amazon streaming, and I don't think it is likely ever to.  If you're a techie I have read that you can get it to stream through Chrome internet browser on your device with a little tweaking, but I have not personally tried that.

review: This device is absolutely phenomenal for the price it is at. My friends and family are speechless when they watch me control everything from my phone. The device is fast, responsive, and doesn't lag. There is really not an noticeable latency between the time you select something on the phone and the time it reacts on the screen. Even if you do notice it, it is so small it doesn't bother you. 4 stars because A. you can't cast Chrome internet videos from your phone to your chromecast (Well, actually, it is in Beta mode, so it will get released.... eventually).  B.I wish there was an option to cast what you are browsing on your phone to the chromecast. I would love to wake up in the morning and read the news on my TV versus my computer or phone. C. Although they have a good selection of apps, they need more. Chromecast offers NOTHING compared to what you can get on Roku which has dozens upon dozens of channels. Chromecast is still an infant, but hopefully time will let it grow up in to something great

review: I spent a long time trying to decide between this and a Roku, and finally went with Chromecast. I'm so glad that I did! It's nice and small and streams everything I've tried so far (Netflix, youtube, Pandora, Plex, Google music) The only thing I did have a little trouble with was streaming video on Amazon, but if you just change your video settings on your browser to flash instead of the default Silverlight, then it works just fine (thought there is a very slight lag between what's playing on, say the computer, and the TV, but you wouldn't even notice it unless you were seeing it on both). It can be powered either through USB or from a wall outlet, which is nice for TVs that don't have a USB connection.  I stream mostly from my phone and so far haven't had any problems. Great buy for the money!! :)
